Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Electrolyte Materials in Energy Storage Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION
The global annual energy consumption is increasing at an unprecedented rate, yet the conventional energy sources are becoming more limited and the general energy use is getting more expensive. Therefore, creative solutions in more efficient energy conversion, storage, and saving become much more critical in the coming decades. In addition, to exploit alternative energy sources, new energy-saving technologies using renewable power sources and more efficient energy storage systems are emerging. Solid oxide fuel cells are regarded as the highest in efficiency amongst all fuel cells and have the promise of low cost in numerous applications. Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, which have dominated the market in portable electronic industry, are viable candidates for powering an increasingly diverse range of devices. In this proposal, we aim to synthesize and optimize a critical and active component in these energy storage devices at miniaturized scales, the electrolyte, to further improve the energy storage density and improve the device performance. The proposed research will serve as a training platform for future generations of engineers, who are not only experienced with cutting-edge research techniques, but are also creative, conscientious and committed to solving the global energy crisis.

TECHNICAL DETAILS
The objective of this research is to synthesize metal oxide based electrolyte materials in miniaturized energy storage devices and investigate their structural properties and ionic conductivity to understand the microscopic pathways governing their performance as an electrolyte, thereby controlling and improving its efficiency. To rationally design an effective electrolyte material with a large contact area with the electrodes, this work will elucidate the growth mechanism of these materials by atomic layer deposition and its effect on controlling the electrolyte?s composition and microstructure and integrate these thin film materials conformally over miniaturized three-dimensional complex structures and assess their ionic conductivity and efficiency. As these metal oxide materials find broader applications in areas including electronics, optics, sensors, and energy storage, this research is transformational in realizing design and optimization of materials with multiple functionalities. This research has a broader impact through the education and training of the future generations of engineers who are skilled with state-of-the-art research techniques and are conscientious, creative, and committed to solve the global energy crisis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lithium ion batteries have been the choice for portable electronics, such as laptops and cell phones. Although technological advancement has produced electronics of smaller size and greater performance, the miniaturization of battery technology has lagged behind, due to the difficulty in simultaneously increasing the power and energy density needed for device operation.  The trade-off between power and energy density has limited further down-scaling of the batteries yet there is an increasing demand for a smaller battery that can power devices longer on a single charge and has a longer lifetime to avoid persistent replacement. For example, the development of novel biomedical sensors and wearable electronics that can monitor environmental cues and relay information wirelessly, calls for smaller batteries that can still meet the energy and power demands of the device.

 

A traditional battery consists of a liquid electrolyte sandwiched between a positive and negative electrode, where lithium ions are transported to provide or store energy. The utilization of a solid electrolyte versus a liquid one, offers increased stability and safety, along with the potential for increased battery performance. A major limitation in the current micro battery design is in the loss of energy storage capacity at reduced dimensions, due to the decreased amount of active material. This has spurred significant research development into novel 3D battery designs that more effectively utilize 3D surface topography to increase the contact area to improve the power and energy densities of the battery. Therefore, this work focused on the development of an atomic layer deposition process (ALD) to synthesize a solid electrolyte that can be conformally deposited over complex micro- and nano- structures. The fine tuning of the elemental composition of the synthesized electrolyte, LixAlySizO, is essential to tailor the electrochemical and mechanical properties of the solid eletrolyte. The charging and discharging test of a prototype all solid state miniaturized 3D battery utilizing this ALD thin film electrolyte demonstrated the feasibility to develop the next generation batteries with higher power and energy densities.
